title: 109_hr200
content: The Act is titled the "Prevention of Predatory Lending Through Education Act" and includes findings related to predatory lending. The Congress finds that expanded access to credit has led to high homeownership rates, but some lenders engage in predatory practices, making it costly for vulnerable families. Borrowers with fair credit can get prime loans with low rates, while those with poor credit get subprime loans with higher rates and fees. Predatory lending involves unjustifiably high interest rates, excessive fees, and other unreasonable terms, particularly targeting minority neighborhoods and cash-poor homeowners. This practice strips away wealth accumulated over decades or a lifetime, victimizing communities lacking access to traditional financial institutions. The joint report by the Department of Housing and Urban Development and the Treasury Department, issued in 2000, called for legislation to curb predatory home mortgage lending by restricting abusive terms, improving consumer disclosures, and prohibiting harmful sales practices in mortgage markets. The joint report in 2000 recommended a four-point plan to address predatory lending practices, including improving consumer literacy and disclosures, prohibiting harmful sales practices in the mortgage market. The 2000 joint report recommended measures to address predatory lending practices, including new requirements for mortgage brokers, restrictions on high-cost loan terms, and improvements to market structure. The report recommended improving market structure by awarding credit under the Community Reinvestment Act to lenders promoting borrowers from subprime to prime mortgages, denying credit for violating lending laws, disclosing high-cost loans in mortgage-backed securities, and disclosing such loans in offering documents. A study found a concentration of subprime lending in minority neighborhoods and to borrowers of color. Government agencies are addressing predatory lending in minority neighborhoods and to borrowers of color at all income levels. The issue involves high-pressure sales tactics, misleading information about interest rates, and threatens the work of nonprofit organizations. More assistance is needed for borrowers with predatory loans, consumer education, and referrals to appropriate agencies for help. Government agencies are addressing predatory lending in minority neighborhoods and to borrowers of color at all income levels. The issue involves high-pressure sales tactics, misleading information about interest rates, and threatens the work of nonprofit organizations. More assistance is needed for borrowers with predatory loans, consumer education, and referrals to appropriate agencies for help. A grant program for education and counseling regarding predatory lending is proposed. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development may provide grants for eligible anti-predatory lending activities to States, local governments, and nonprofit organizations. These activities include education programs to inform vulnerable consumers about predatory lending practices related to home loans with high interest rates and excessive fees. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development may provide grants for anti-predatory lending activities, including counseling programs and referral services for homeowners and prospective homeowners to address unfair lending practices. To be eligible for a grant under this section, applicants must submit an application with required information. The maximum grant amount for any single grantee in a fiscal year is $1,000,000. The Secretary will select applicants for the grants. The Secretary will select applicants for grants up to $1,000,000 in a fiscal year from States, local governments, and nonprofit organizations based on established criteria. The Secretary will establish a toll-free telephone number for predatory lending complaints and create a predatory lending advisory council. Established in the Department of Housing and Urban Development is a Predatory Lending Advisory Council to advise the Secretary on issues related to predatory lending practices for home loans. The Council consists of 13 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives of community-based organizations and State agencies. The Predatory Lending Advisory Council in the Department of Housing and Urban Development consists of 13 members appointed by the Secretary. The Council includes representatives from State agencies, private homeowners familiar with mortgages, and the real estate industry. Members serve two-year terms with travel expenses covered. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment process. The Predatory Lending Advisory Council in the Department of Housing and Urban Development consists of 13 members appointed by the Secretary, with a designated chairperson. The Council meets at least three times a year, has advisory functions including providing advice on grant programs and toll-free telephone numbers. The Predatory Lending Advisory Council in the Department of Housing and Urban Development is responsible for coordinating activities to prevent predatory lending practices related to home loans. They also conduct a study on the root causes of defaults and foreclosures, providing recommendations for consumer protection legislation. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. The term "home loan" under this Act refers to a loan secured by residential property, including home equity lines of credit and home improvement loans. "Nonprofit organization" is defined as per the Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act. The term "predatory or unscrupulous lending practice" includes making loans solely based on home equity, without considering the borrower's ability to repay, and that are unaffordable, leading to difficulties in meeting mortgage payments or foreclosure. The term "predatory or unscrupulous lending practice" includes inducing borrowers to refinance repeatedly and engaging in fraud to conceal the true nature of the loan obligation. The term "unit of general local government" refers to any city, town, township, parish, village, or other political subdivision of a State. Authorization of Appropriations: $55,000,000 authorized for fiscal years 2006-2010. $2,000,000 for section 4 and $5,000,000 for section 5. Secretary may issue necessary regulations.
